Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Web.Mobile.dll assembly has been deprecated and should no longer be used. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=157231.")

Docs.summary: Enables you to specify multiple fields for display, per item in an object list. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Much of the behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>, including support for templated rendering through device template sets and internal pagination, is similar to the behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.List>. For more information, see the [Introduction to the ObjectList Control](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-3.0/d7hb3s0f(v=vs.85)) or the [Pagination](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b4f4c4bc-226b-46ec-ae46-00497a32f4f2) documentation.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create an array of a user-defined class and then bind it to an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> object when the page loads. It also shows how the list and details views display the commands. For this example, there is also a button that displays a form with a list of all the fields using the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AllFields%2A> property.
> [!NOTE] > The following code sample uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code sample must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).
[!code-aspx-csharp[MobileObjectListSample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileObjectListSample/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[MobileObjectListSample#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileObjectListSample/vb/Default.aspx#1)]
This is a sample Web.config file with several device specific filters.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property AllFields As IObjectListFieldCollection

Docs.summary: Returns the collection of all fields from the class, whether explicit or automatically generated. The default value is the collection of automatically generated fields. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: An object containing all fields in the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This collection is available only after data binding. Unlike the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.Fields%2A> collection, you cannot add or remove items in this collection. By default, this collection is the set of automatically generated fields. If any fields are explicitly defined, they are contained after any automatically generated fields.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AllFields%2A> property to list all the fields of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>. This example is part of a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> overview.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool AutoGenerateFields { bool get(); void set(bool value); };
member this.AutoGenerateFields : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Specifies whether fields must be automatically generated from data. When enabled, each public property of the data becomes a field of the control. The default value is . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: if the fields are automatically generated from data; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When `true`, the object list handles the fields order in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListFieldCollection> collection. When `false`, you must specify the order of the fields and set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileListItem.DataItem%2A> property to bind to a data source.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.AutoGenerateFields%2A> property to statically associate the fields with their collection in the Details view of an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> control.
> [!NOTE] > The following code sample uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code sample must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Web::UI::MobileControls::Style ^ CommandStyle { System::Web::UI::MobileControls::Style ^ get(); void set(System::Web::UI::MobileControls::Style ^ value); };
member this.CommandStyle : System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Style with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the style used for the object list commands. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The style used for the object list commands.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If this property is programmatically set, it is not persisted unless the property is set dynamically on each request. If the property is set declaratively, the property is set on each request. There is no default.
Since different devices have different requirements for styles. You may want several <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.DeviceSpecific%2A> settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.CommandStyle%2A> property.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to the use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.CommandStyle%2A> property to set the style of an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> using a declarative <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.DeviceSpecific> section to specify different <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.CommandStyle%2A> settings for different devices.
> [!NOTE] > The following code sample uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code sample must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the data source of the list that is being bound. The default value is null. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The data source of the list that is being bound.

remarks.format: ## Remarks To bind a data source to a list, you must first use the control's <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DataBind%2A> method to ensure data binding. The data source can be of type <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable> or of type <xref:System.ComponentModel.IListSource>. If the data source is of type <xref:System.ComponentModel.IListSource>, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DataMember%2A> field to specify which member to extract.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ DefaultCommand { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.DefaultCommand : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the default command. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The name of the default command.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When set, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> control attempts to render a shortcut to invoke the default command. In HTML, the default rendering in list view displays the first field as a link to the details view of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>. When the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property is set, clicking the link invokes the default command. Invoking the default command raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs.CommandName%2A> of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandEventArgs> object is set to the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property.
Even if a default command is defined, you should include a command with the same name in the commands collection. If the control cannot render a graphical element that includes a shortcut for the default command, the default command is still available through the rendering of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> commands collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The details view has a table that lists each field title and value. In addition, it lists all the commands associated with an item. For some devices, this view also contains a link that returns the user to the list view.

Docs.exception: the current view is not the details view.

remarks.format:

> [!NOTE] > This label is displayed only on WAP browsers.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event ItemCommand As ObjectListCommandEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when the user selects a command that is associated with an item. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event handler is defined, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> notifies the handler when an item event is generated through user interaction.
When you render an object list by using templates, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event handler is called through the event-bubbling mechanism of ASP.NET. The event handler is passed an argument of type <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandEventArgs>, which contains information about the source item and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs.CommandName%2A> property of the control that generated the event. This allows you to render a single item with multiple associated interactions.
On default rendering, the control renders each of the commands defined for the object list as a link. When the user clicks a link, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event handler is called with an argument of type <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandEventArgs>, which contains information about the source item. The value in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs.CommandName%2A> property is the name of the command that the user invoked.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to trap the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs.CommandName%2A> property specifies what action to perform.
> [!NOTE] > The following code sample uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code sample must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event ItemDataBind As ObjectListDataBindEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when an item in an is bound to data. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When an item in an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> is created and data-bound, this event handler sets the properties of the list item from arbitrary expressions. An item in an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> control is of type <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListItem>.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemDataBind> event. You can use either the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListDataBindEventArgs.ListItem%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListDataBindEventArgs.DataItem%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListDataBindEventArgs> collection to determine further action. This example is part of a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> overview.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the style used for the header label. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The style used for the header label.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Setting this property in code is not persisted between requests, so if you want the style to be consistently set, you must set the property on each request. If the property is set declaratively, the property is persisted between requests. In addition, setting the property declaratively allows you to use a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.DeviceSpecific>/`Choice` structure to set the property for various devices.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ MoreText { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.MoreText : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text string used for the link used on HTML browsers to navigate to the details view. The default is or the localized equivalent. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The text string used for the link used on HTML browsers to navigate to the details view.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `More` link is rendered to provide a link from the `ListView` of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> to the `DetailsView` of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>. The following conditions must be met for the `More` link to be rendered:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property must be set.
- There must be additional fields or commands to be rendered in the details view.
The default rendering of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> displays the first field in the `ListView` as a link to the `DetailsView` page. Setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DefaultCommand%2A> property overrides this link and causes it to raise the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemCommand> event. As a result, the `More` link is rendered to provide a link to the `DetailsView`.
> [!NOTE] > This property is not the same as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.DetailsCommandText%2A> property, which is used on WAP browsers.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method notifies a server control to perform any logic for binding data that is associated with it.
If you want to handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.DataBinding> event, you should override this event-handling method. This ensures that all delegates attached to the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.DataBinding> event are invoked.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event ShowItemCommands As ObjectListShowCommandsEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs before the commands related to an item in an are shown. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The event argument contains a reference to the item and to the collection of commands. An event handler can customize the collection according to the item. Applications can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ShowItemCommands> event to provide functionality equivalent to item-specific shortcut menus. Changes made to the collection of commands during this event are not persisted.
This event is called after the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ItemSelect> event is called. You can use this event to perform other tasks before showing the detail view. You can add, remove, or rearrange fields, depending on the item selected in the list view.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.ShowItemCommands> event to remove an item from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListCommandCollection> of the detail view of an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>. The item to remove is selected in the list view.
> [!NOTE] > The following code sample uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code sample must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).
[!code-aspx-csharp[MobileObjectListSample#10](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileObjectListSample/cs/Default3.aspx#10)] [!code-aspx-vb[MobileObjectListSample#10](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileObjectListSample/vb/Default3.aspx#10)]

Docs.summary: Gets an array of indices within the collection of the fields in the property. The default value is . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: An array of integers representing the indices of the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> control has not been bound to a data source or no items have been added, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.TableFieldIndices%2A> property returns `null`.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ TableFields { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.TableFields : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets which fields are visible when the list view is shown in table mode. The default value is an empty string (""). This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: A semicolon-delimited list of fields to be displayed when the list view is shown in table mode.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This string must be a set of identifiers, separated by semicolons. Each identifier indicates the name or data field of the field that will be displayed. By default, the list view is never shown in table mode unless this property is not empty.
## Examples For a complete code sample, see the example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> overview.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Web::UI::MobileControls::ObjectListViewMode ViewMode { System::Web::UI::MobileControls::ObjectListViewMode get(); void set(System::Web::UI::MobileControls::ObjectListViewMode value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the view mode of an . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: An value representing the view mode of the object list.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following options are available for this property through the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode> enumeration.
|Member Name|Description| |-----------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.List>|This is the default view displayed when the page containing the object list is rendered for the first time. It consists of either the label fields of the items, or if the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList.TableFields%2A> property is not empty, a table with columns corresponding to the table fields and rows for the items. In HTML, this view is combined with the Commands view, with the commands appearing as hyperlinks below the list. When there is more information in the Details view, a hyperlink for each item displaying the Details view is rendered.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.Details>|In HTML, this view is combined with the Commands view, with the commands appearing as hyperlinks below the details.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.Commands>|This view is rendered separately only for WML devices. It consists of a menu with the commands of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList>. For HTML devices, the List view and Details view are each combined with this view, with the commands appearing as hyperlinks below the details or list.|
> [!NOTE] > To set this property in code, an item in the list must be selected before setting this property to <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.Commands> or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectListViewMode.Details> view. An attempt to set the property before selecting an item throws an exception.
A view mode is persisted in a private view state, so that, regardless of whether the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> object is `true`, the view mode is persisted as a private field. However, if the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.EnableViewState%2A> property is `false`, the items collection is not persisted between requests, requiring a data bind to be repeated for each request.

Docs.exception: An attempt was made to set this property to a value other than while no item was selected.
